question: Question 1 The transfer function of a real system, [latex]H(s)[/latex], is given as: [latex]H(s)=\frac{As+B}{s^2+Cs+D}[/latex] where A, B, C and D are positive constants. This system cannot operate as
solution:
Put [latex] s=0, H(0)=\frac{A \times 0+B}{0+C \times 0+D}=\frac{B}{D}[/latex] So, the system pass low frequency component.
Put [latex] s=\infty , H(\infty )=0[/latex] For high pass filter, high frequency component
should be non zero. Hence this system cannot
be operated as high pass filter.

question:
Question 2 For an ideal MOSFET biased in saturation, the magnitude of the small signal
current gain for a common drain amplifier is
solution: For ideal MOSFET, [latex] i_G=0[/latex] Therefore, Current gain, [latex] A_I=\frac{i_s}{i_G}=\infty [/latex]

Question 4 The geometric mean radius of a conductor, having four equal strands with each strand
of radius [latex] 'r'[/latex], as shown in the figure below, is

a 220 kV, fully transposed three-phase transmission line, from the given choices are
solution:
We have, [latex] X_0 \gt X_1=X_2[/latex] (for [latex] 3-\phi [/latex] transposed
transmission line)

question: Question 6 The steady state output ([latex]V_{out}[/latex]), of the circuit shown below, will
solution:
Redraw the circuit: From circuit, [latex] \begin{aligned}
V_{out} &=-\frac{1}{C_1}\int I\cdot dt \\ 
 &= -\frac{1}{R_1C_1}\int 0 \cdot 1dt \\ \\ 
 &=-\frac{0.1}{R_1C_1}\int  dt \\  \\ 
 &= -\frac{0.1}{R_1C_1}t 
\end{aligned} [/latex] Hence, [latex] V_{out}=-V_{EE}[/latex]

question:
Question 7 The Bode magnitude plot of a first order stable system is constant with frequency.
The asymptotic value of the high frequency phase, for the system, is [latex]-180^{\circ}[/latex]. This
system has
solution:
The given system is non-minimum phase system
Therefore, transfer function, [latex] T.F=\frac{s-1}{s+1} [/latex] Hence, one LHP pole and one RHP zero at the
same frequency.

options.A: one LHP pole and one RHP zero at the same frequency
options.B: one LHP pole and one LHP zero at the same frequency
options.C: two LHP poles and one RHP zero
options.D: two RHP poles and one LHP zero.

question: Question 8 A balanced Wheatstone bridge [latex]ABCD[/latex] has the following arm resistances: [latex]R_{AB}=1k\Omega \pm 2.1%; R_{BC}=100\Omega \pm 0.5%, R_{CD}[/latex] is an unknown resistance; [latex]R_{DA}=300\Omega \pm 0.4%; [/latex]. The value of [latex]R_{CD}[/latex] and its accuracy is
solution:
The condition for balanced bridge [latex] \begin{aligned}
 R_{AB}R_{CD}&=R_{DA}R_{BC} \\ 
R_{CD} &=\frac{300 \times 100}{1000}=30\Omega  \\ 
 %Error &=\pm (2.1+0.5+0.4)=\pm 3% \\ 
 \therefore \; R_{CD}&=30\pm 30 \times \frac{3}{100}=30\pm 0.9\Omega  
\end{aligned} [/latex]

question: Question 9 The open loop transfer function of a unity gain negative feedback system is given by [latex]G(s)=\frac{k}{s^2+4s-5}[/latex]. The range of [latex]k[/latex] for which the system is stable, is
solution:
Characteristic equation: [latex] \begin{aligned}
 1+G(s)H(s)&=0\\
1+\frac{k}{s^2+4s-5}&=0\\
s^2+4s+k-5&=0 
\end{aligned} [/latex] R-H criteria: [latex] \left.\begin{matrix}
s^2\\ 
s^1\\ 
s^0
\end{matrix}\right| \begin{matrix}
1 & k-5\\ 
4 & 0\\ 
k-5 & 
\end{matrix}[/latex] Hence, for stable system, [latex] k-5  \gt 0 \;\;
\Rightarrow \; k  \gt 5[/latex]

question: Question 10 Consider a 3 x 3 matrix A whose (i,j)-th element, [latex]a_{i,j}=(i-j)^3[/latex]. Then the matrix A will be
solution: [latex] for \; i=j\Rightarrow a_{ij}=(i-i)^3=0\forall i[/latex] [latex] for \; i\neq j\Rightarrow a_{ij}=(i-j)^3=(-(j-i))^3=-(j-i)^3=-a_{ji}[/latex] [latex] \therefore \; A_{3 \times 3 }[/latex]  is skew symmetric matrix.

question:
Question 11 In the circuit shown below, a three-phase star-connected unbalanced load is connected
to a balanced three-phase supply of [latex]100\sqrt{3}[/latex] with phase sequence [latex]ABC[/latex]. The star
connected load has [latex]Z_A=10\Omega[/latex] and [latex]Z_B=20\angle 60^{\circ}[/latex]. The value of [latex]Z_C[/latex] in [latex]\Omega[/latex], for which
the voltage difference across the nodes [latex]n[/latex]and [latex]n'[/latex] is zero, is
solution: Given: n & n' are at same potential, therefore, [latex] I_{nn'}=0[/latex] [latex] I_{A}+I_{B}+I_{C}=0[/latex] [latex] \frac{E_A}{Z_A}+\frac{E_B}{Z_B}+\frac{E_C}{Z_C}=0[/latex] where , [latex] E_A=100\angle 0^{\circ}V \text{ and }Z_A=10\Omega  [/latex] [latex] E_B=100\angle -120^{\circ}V \text{ and }Z_B=20\angle 60^{\circ}  [/latex] [latex] E_C=100\angle 120^{\circ}V \text{ and }Z_C=?  [/latex] [latex] \therefore \frac{100\angle 0^{\circ}}{10}+\frac{100\angle -120^{\circ}}{20\angle 60^{\circ} }+\frac{100\angle 120^{\circ}}{Z_C}=0[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow Z_C=20\angle -60^{\circ} \Omega [/latex]

question:
Question 12 A charger supplies 100 W at 20 V for charging the battery of a laptop. The power
devices, used in the converter inside the charger, operate at a switching frequency of
200 kHz. Which power device is best suited for this purpose?
solution: Ratings of different power devices: BJT : 1200 V, 800 A, (10 - 20)kHz SCR : 10000 V, 3000 A IGBT : 1200 V, 500 A, 50 kHz MOSFET : 500 V, 140 A, 1 MHz

question:
Question 13 A long conducting cylinder having a radius 'b' is placed along the z axis. The current
density is [latex]J=J_ar^3\hat{z}[/latex] for the region [latex]r \lt b[/latex] where [latex]r[/latex] is the distance in the radial direction.
The magnetic field intensity ([latex]H[/latex]) for the region inside the conductor (i.e. for [latex]r \lt b[/latex]) is
solution:
Using Ampere?s law, [latex] \begin{aligned}
 \oint \vec{H}\cdot d\vec{l}&=I_{enc}\\
\text{where, }I_{enc}&=\int \int \vec{J}\cdot d\vec{s}\\
d\vec{s}&=rdrd\phi \hat{a}_z\\
\therefore \oint \vec{H}\cdot d\vec{l}&=\int \int \vec{J}\cdot r^3\hat{a}_z\cdot rdrd\phi \hat{a}_z\\
\vec{H}\cdot 2 \pi r&=\frac{J_ar^5}{5}(2 \pi)\\
\Rightarrow \vec{H}&=\frac{J_ar^4}{5}A/m
\end{aligned} [/latex]

factor during steady state running condition, is
Question 15 For the circuit shown below with ideal diodes, the output will be
solution:
Case (i): For positive half cycle of [latex] V_i[/latex] Diode [latex] D_1[/latex] 
 & [latex] D_2[/latex] are in forward biased. Redraw
the circuit: So, [latex] V_o=V_{in}[/latex] Case (ii): For negative half cycle of [latex] V_i[/latex] Both diodes [latex] D_1[/latex] 
 & [latex] D_2[/latex] are in reverse biased. Redraw the circuit: Hence, [latex] V_o=V_{in} \text{ for } V_{in} \gt 0[/latex]

question:
Question 16 A MOD 2 and a MOD 5 up-counter when cascaded together results in a MOD ______
counter. (in integer)
solution: Overall MOD = 2 x 5 = 10

question:
Question 17 An inductor having a Q-factor of 60 is connected in series with a capacitor having a Q-factor of 240. The overall Q-factor of the circuit is ________. (round off to nearest
integer)
solution: We have, overall Q-factor of given circuit is, [latex] Q=\frac{Q_LQ_C}{Q_L+Q_C}=\frac{60 \times 240}{60+240}=48 [/latex]

question:
Question 18 The network shown below has a resonant frequency of 150 kHz and a bandwidth of
600 Hz. The Q-factor of the network is __________. (round off to nearest integer)
solution: [latex] Q=\frac{\omega _o}{BW}=\frac{f_o}{BW}=\frac{150 \times 10^3}{600}=250 [/latex]

question:
Question 19 The maximum clock frequency in MHz of a 4-stage ripple counter, utilizing flipflops, with each flip-flop having a propagation delay of 20 ns, is ___________.
(round off to one decimal place)
solution: [latex] f_{max}=\frac{1}{nt_p}=\frac{1}{4 \times 20 \times 10^{-9}}=12.50MHz [/latex]

question:
Question 20 If only 5% of the supplied power to a cable reaches the output terminal, the power loss
in the cable, in decibels, is _________. (round off to nearest integer)
solution:
We have, the power loss (in decibel) in the cable
is given power loss = 95% Power output as a % of power is 5% [latex]P_L=10 \log \left ( \frac{95}{5} \right )=12.78 [/latex]

question:
Question 21 In the circuit shown below, the switch [latex]S[/latex] is closed at [latex]t=0[/latex]. The magnitude of the steady
state voltage, in volts, across the [latex]6 \Omega [/latex] resistor is _________. (round off to two decimal
places).
solution:
Concept: At steady state, capacitor behaves as
open circuit. Using voltage division, [latex]V=\frac{2}{2+2} \times 10=5V [/latex]

question:
Question 22 A single-phase full-bridge diode rectifier feeds a resistive load of [latex]50 \Omega [/latex] from a [latex]200 V,
50 Hz[/latex] single phase AC supply. If the diodes are ideal, then the active power, in watts,
drawn by the load is _____________. (round off to nearest integer).
solution: For [latex]1-\phi [/latex] full bridge diode rectifier: [latex]V_{or}=\frac{V_m}{\sqrt{2}} =\frac{\sqrt{2} \times 200}{\sqrt{2}}=200V[/latex] Active power drawn by the load [latex]P_{o}=\frac{V_{or}^2}{R} =\frac{200^2}{50}=800W[/latex]

question: Question 23 The voltage at the input of an AC-DC rectifier is given by [latex] v(t)=230\sqrt{2}\sin \omega t[/latex] where [latex]  \omega = 2 \pi \times 50[/latex] rad/s. The input current drawn by the rectifier is given by [latex]i(t)=10\sin \left (\omega t -\frac{\pi}{3} \right )+4\sin \left (3\omega t -\frac{\pi}{6} \right )+3\sin \left (5\omega t -\frac{\pi}{3} \right )[/latex] The input power factor, (rounded off to two decimal places), is, _________ lag.
solution:
We have, [latex]\begin{aligned}
 PF&=g.FDF \\ 
 g&=\frac{I_{{s1}}}{I_{sr}} \\ 
 &= \frac{10/\sqrt{2}}{\sqrt{\left ( \frac{10}{\sqrt{2}} \right )^2+\left ( \frac{4}{\sqrt{2}} \right )^2+\left ( \frac{3}{\sqrt{2}} \right )^2}}\\ 
 &=0.894 \\ 
 FDF&= \cos \frac{\pi}{3}=0.5 \\ 
 PF&=0.894 \times 0.5=0.447 
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 24 Two balanced three-phase loads, as shown in the figure, are connected to a [latex]100\sqrt{3}V [/latex],
three-phase, 50 Hz main supply. Given [latex] Z_1=(18+j24)\Omega [/latex] and [latex] Z_2=(6+j8)\Omega [/latex]. The
ammeter reading, in amperes, is _______. (round off to nearest integer)
solution:
First perform delta to star conversion
we know, for balanced load [latex]Z_{star}=\frac{Z_{delta}}{3}=\frac{18+j24}{3}=6+j8\Omega [/latex] Draw the per phase diagram: [latex]Z_{eq}=(6+j8)||(6+j8)=(3+j8)\Omega =5\angle 53.13^{\circ} \Omega [/latex] Therefore, Meter reading, [latex]I=\frac{100}{5}=20A [/latex]

question:
Question 25 The frequencies of the stator and rotor currents flowing in a three-phase 8-pole
induction motor are 40 Hz and 1 Hz, respectively. The motor speed, in rpm, is
_______. (round off to nearest integer)
solution:
We have, [latex]f_r=sf_s[/latex] Slip, 
[latex]s=\frac{1}{40}=0.025 [/latex] Now, speed [latex]N=N_s(1-s)=\frac{120 \times 40}{8}(1-0.025)=585rpm [/latex]

question:
Question 26 The output impedance of a non-ideal operational amplifier is denoted by [latex] Z_{out} [/latex]. The
variation in the magnitude of [latex] Z_{out} [/latex] with increasing frequency, [latex] f [/latex], in the circuit shown
below, is best represented by
solution:
Bode plot of negative feedback amplifier: Given amplifier is a voltage series feedback amplifier. Therefore, Output impedance is given by [latex]Z_{out}=\frac{Z_o}{1+A\beta } =\frac{Z_o}{1+A } \;\;\;(\beta=1 \text{ for buffer})[/latex] From Bode plot ; at low frequency, the open
loop gain (A) is constant. when [latex]\omega \uparrow, A \downarrow,Z_{out}\uparrow[/latex] At [latex]A=0, Z_{out}=Z_o\rightarrow constant[/latex] Therefore,  [latex]z_{out}  [/latex] with frequency represented by

question: Question 27 An LTI system is shown in the figure where [latex]G(s)=\frac{100}{s^2+0.1s+10}[/latex] The steady state output of the system, to the input [latex]r(t) [/latex], is given as [latex]y(t)=a+b\sin (10t+\theta )[/latex]. The values of [latex]a [/latex] and [latex]b [/latex] will be
solution:
We knaow, [latex] y(t)=A|G(j\omega ) \sin (\omega t+\phi )[/latex] Here, 
[latex] G(j\omega )=\frac{100}{-\omega ^2+j0.1\omega +100} [/latex] Put
[latex]\omega =0  [/latex] [latex]|G(j\omega )|=1  [/latex] Now, put 
[latex] \omega =10  [/latex] rad/sec [latex] |G(j\omega )|=\left | \frac{100}{-100+i1+100} \right |=100 [/latex] Therefore,
[latex] y(t)=1+0.1 \times 100 \sin(10t+\theta ) =1+10 \sin (10t+\theta )[/latex] On comparision 
[latex]  : a=1 ,b=10[/latex]

question:
Question 28 The open loop transfer function of a unity gain negative feedback system is given
as [latex] G(s)=\frac{1}{s(s+1)}[/latex] The Nyquist contour in the s-plane encloses the entire right half plane and a small
neighbourhood around the origin in the left half plane, as shown in the figure below.
The number of encirclements of the point [latex] (-1+j0)[/latex] by the Nyquist plot of [latex] G(s)[/latex],
corresponding to the Nyquist contour, is denoted as [latex] N[/latex]. Then [latex]N[/latex] equals to
solution:
Given: P = 1 (Because, Nyquist contour encircle one
pole i.e s = 0) We have, N = P - Z N = 1-Z Characteristic equation [latex]\begin{aligned}
1+G(s)H(s) &=0 \\ 
 1+\frac{k}{s(s+1)}&=0 \\ 
 s^2+s+k&= 0
\end{aligned}[/latex] R-H criteria: [latex] \left.\begin{matrix}
s^2\\ 
s^1\\ 
s^0
\end{matrix}\right| \begin{matrix}
1 & k\\ 
1 & 0\\ 
k & 
\end{matrix}[/latex] Hence, z = 0 (because no sign change in first
column of R-H criteria) (where, z = closed loop pole on RHS side of s-plane) Therefore, N = 1

question:
Question 29 The damping ratio and undamped natural frequency of a closed loop system as
shown in the figure, are denoted as [latex] \zeta[/latex] and 
[latex]  \omega _n[/latex], respectively. The values of [latex] \zeta[/latex] and [latex]  \omega _n[/latex] are
solution:
Reduced the block diagram: Transfer function, [latex] \frac{C(s)}{R(s)}=\frac{100/(s(s+10))}{1+(100/s(s+10))}=\frac{100}{s^2+10s+100}[/latex] Standard form, [latex] T.F.=\frac{\omega _n^2}{s^2+2\xi \omega _ns+\omega _n^2}[/latex] On comparison :
[latex] \omega =\sqrt{100}=10rad/sec[/latex] and 
[latex] 2\xi \omega _n=10[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow  \xi=\frac{10}{2 \times 10}=0.5 [/latex]

question: Question 30 [latex] e^A[/latex] denotes the exponential of a square matrix A. Suppose [latex]\lambda [/latex] is an eigenvalue and [latex]v [/latex] is the corresponding eigen-vector of matrix A. Consider the following two statements: Statement 1: [latex] e^\lambda [/latex] is an eigenvalue of [latex] e^A[/latex]. Statement 2: [latex]v [/latex]is an eigen-vector of [latex] e^A[/latex]. Which one of the following options is correct?
solution:
Eigen value will change but eigen vector not
change.

options.A: Statement 1 is true and statement 2 is false.
options.B: Statement 1 is false and statement 2 is true

question: Question 31 Let [latex] f(x)=\int_{0}^{x}e^t(t-1)(t-2)dt [/latex]. Then [latex] f(x)[/latex]  decreases in the interval
solution:
The function is decreasing, if 
[latex]f'(x) \lt 0 [/latex] [latex]f'(x)=\frac{d}{dx} \int_{0}^{x}e^t(t-1)(t-2)dt [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \; e^x(x-1)(x-2) \lt 0[/latex] It is possible in between 1 & 2. Hence
[latex]x \in (1,2) [/latex]

question:
Question 32 Consider a matrix [latex]  A=\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0 & 0\\ 
0 & 4 & -2\\ 
 0&1  &1 
\end{bmatrix}[/latex] The matrix [latex]A[/latex] satisfies the equation [latex] 6A^{-1}=A^2+cA+dI[/latex] where [latex] c[/latex] and [latex] d[/latex] are
scalars and [latex] I[/latex] is the identity matrix. Then [latex] (c+d)[/latex] is equal to

Question 33 The fuel cost functions in rupees/hour for two 600 MW thermal power plants are
given by [latex] Plant 1: \; C_1=350+6P_1+0.004P_1^2[/latex] [latex] Plant 2: \; C_2=450+aP_2+0.003P_2^2[/latex] where [latex] P_1[/latex] and [latex] P_2[/latex] are power generated by plant 1 and plant 2, respectively, in MW
and [latex]a[/latex] is constant. The incremental cost of power [latex] (\lambda )[/latex] is 8 rupees per MWh. The two
thermal power plants together meet a total power demand of 550 MW. The optimal
generation of plant 1 and plant 2 in MW, respectively, are
solution:
[latex] \frac{dC_1}{dP_1}=IC_1=6+0.008P_1[/latex] [latex] \frac{dC_2}{dP_2}=IC_2=a+0.006P_2[/latex] For optimum generation, [latex] IC_1=IC_2=\lambda[/latex] Therefore, 
[latex]6+0.008P_1=8 [/latex] [latex]P_1=250MW [/latex] Given, 
[latex]P_1+P_2=550MW [/latex] [latex] P_550-250=300MW[/latex]

question:
Question 34 The current gain [latex](I_{out}/I_{in})[/latex] in the circuit with an ideal current amplifier given below
is
solution:
Redraw the circuit: From circuit, [latex] \begin{aligned}
 V_o&=V_c \\ 
 &=\frac{1}{C_f}\int I_{in}dt \\ 
 I_{out}&=C_c\frac{dV_o}{dt} \\ 
 &= C_c\frac{d}{dt}\left ( \frac{1}{C_f} \int I_{in}dt\right )\\
&=\frac{C_c}{C_f}I_{in}\\
\Rightarrow \frac{I_{out}}{I_{in}}&=\frac{C_c}{C_f}
\end{aligned} [/latex]

question:
Question 35 If the magnetic field intensity [latex](H) [/latex] in a conducting region is given by the expression, [latex]H=x^2\hat{i}+x^2y^2\hat{j}+x^2y^2z^2\hat{k}\;A/m[/latex]. The magnitude of the current density, in [latex]A/m^2[/latex]
, at [latex]x=1m, y=2m [/latex] and [latex]z=1m [/latex], is
solution:
We have, [latex] \begin{aligned}
 \vec{J}&=\triangledown  \times \vec{H}\\
\vec{J}&=\begin{vmatrix}
\hat{a}_x &\hat{a}_y  & \hat{a}_z\\ 
 \frac{\partial }{\partial x}& \frac{\partial }{\partial y} &\frac{\partial }{\partial z} \\ 
 x^2& x^2y^2 & x^2y^2z^2
\end{vmatrix} \\
&=\hat{a}_x(2x^2yz^2-0)-\hat{a}_y(2xy^2z^2-0)+\hat{a}_z(2xy^2-0)\\
&=2x^2yz^2\hat{a}_x-2xy^2z^2\hat{a}_y+2xy^2\hat{a}_z\\
&\text{At point (1,2,1)}\\
\vec{J}&=4\hat{a}_x-8\hat{a}_y+8\hat{a}_z\\
|\vec{J}|&=\sqrt{4^2+8^2+8^2}=12A/m^2
\end{aligned} [/latex]

question:
Question 36 Let a causal LTI system be governed by the following differential equation [latex]y(t)+\frac{1}{4}\frac{dy}{dt}=2x(t) [/latex], where [latex]x(t) [/latex] and [latex]x(t) [/latex] are the input and output respectively.
Its impulse response is
solution:
Given: [latex]  y(t)+\frac{1}{4}\frac{dy}{dt}=2x(t)[/latex] Taking Laplace transform, [latex]Y(s)+\frac{1}{4}(sY(s))=2X(s) [/latex] Now, 
[latex]H(s)=\frac{Y(s)}{X(s)}=\frac{2}{\frac{s}{4}+1}=\frac{8}{s+4} [/latex] Taking inverse Laplace, transform, [latex]h(t)=8e^{-4t}u(t) [/latex]

question:
Question 37 Let an input [latex]x(t)=2 \sin (10 \pi t)+5 \cos (15 \pi t)+7  \sin (42 \pi t)+4 \cos (45 \pi t) [/latex] is
passed through an LTI system having an impulse response, [latex] h(t)=2\left ( \frac{\sin (10 \pi t)}{\pi t} \right ) \cos (40\pi t)[/latex] The output of the system is
solution:
Given: [latex]h(t)=2\left ( \frac{\sin (10 \pi t)}{\pi t} \right ) \cos 40 \pi t [/latex] Fourier transform of signal [latex] \frac{\sin (10 \pi t)}{\pi t}[/latex] is given
by Now, impulse response [latex]h(t)=2\left ( \frac{\sin (10 \pi t)}{\pi t} \right )\cdot \left ( \frac{e^{+j40\pi t}+e^{-j40\pi t}}{2} \right ) [/latex] Using property,
[latex] e^{-j\omega _0t}x(t)\rightleftharpoons X(\omega +\omega _0)[/latex] Therefore, Fourier transform of impulse response Cut-off frequencies, [latex]\omega_L=30 \pi rad/sec [/latex] [latex]\omega_H=50 \pi rad/sec [/latex] Thus, output of the system 
[latex] =7 \sin 42 \pi t+4 \cos 45 \pi t[/latex]

question: Question 38 Consider the system as shown below where [latex]y(t)=x(e^t) [/latex]. The system is
solution:
We know, a linear system follows the law of
superposition. It is a combination of two laws: (i) Law of additivity: Both results are same, hence, it follows law
of additivity. (ii) Law of Homogeneity: Here also both results are same, hence it
follows law of Homogeneity. Therefore, System is linear. We know, a causal system is independent
of future values of input at each & every
instant of time them system will be causal. Given : 
[latex]y(t)=x(e^t) [/latex] Put 
[latex]t=0 [/latex] [latex]y(0)=x(e^0)=x(1)  [/latex] Because  its depends on future value. Therefore,  system is non-causal.

question:
Question 39 The discrete time Fourier series representation of a signal [latex]x[n] [/latex] with period [latex]N [/latex] is
written as [latex]x[n]=\sum_{k=0}^{N-1}a_ke^{j(2kn\pi/N)} [/latex]. A discrete time periodic signal with period [latex]N=3 [/latex], has the non-zero Fourier series coefficients: [latex]a_{-3}=2 [/latex] and [latex]a_4=1 [/latex]. The
signal is
solution:
Given:
[latex]x(n)=\sum_{k=0}^{N-1}a_ke^{j\frac{2 \pi kn}{N}} [/latex] [latex] \therefore \; x(n)=a_0+a_1e^{\frac{j2\pi n}{3}}+0+... \;\;\;...(1)[/latex] We have, [latex]a_k=a_{k+N} [/latex] [latex]a_0=a_3 [/latex] [latex]a_1=a_4=1 [/latex] [latex]a_{-3}=a_0=2 [/latex] Put n = 0 in eq. (1) [latex]x(0)=a_0+a_1=2+1=3 [/latex] Put n = 1 in eq. (1) [latex]x(1)=a_0+a_1e^{j 2 \pi /3}=2+1\left ( \cos \frac{2\pi}{3} +j \sin \frac{2\pi}{3}\right )=2+(-0.5+j0.866)=1.5+j0.866 [/latex] These two conditions satisfy by the option (B).
Hence, option (B) will be correct.

question: Question 40 Let, [latex] f(x,y,z)=4x^2+7xy+3xz^2[/latex]. The direction in which the function [latex]f(x,y,z)[/latex] increases most rapidly at point [latex] P = (1,0,2)[/latex] is
solution:
Given:
[latex]f(x,y,z)=4x^2+7xy+3xz^2 [/latex] The directional derivative at point P is given by [latex]=\triangledown f|_{point \; P} [/latex] [latex] \therefore \; \triangledown f=(8x+7y+3z^2)\hat{i}+(0+7x+0)\hat{j}+(0+0+6xz)\hat{k}[/latex] at point (1, 0, 2) [latex]\triangledown f|_{(1,0,2)}=20\hat{i}+7\hat{j}+12\hat{k} [/latex]

question:
Question 41 Let [latex] R[/latex] be a region in the first quadrant of the [latex] xy[/latex] plane enclosed by a closed curve [latex] C[/latex]
considered in counter-clockwise direction. Which of the following expressions does
not represent the area of the region [latex] R[/latex]?
solution:
Using green theorem?s [latex] \oint _cF_1dx+F_2dy=\int \int _R\left ( \frac{\partial F_2}{\partial x} -\frac{\partial F_1}{\partial y}\right )dxdy [/latex] Check all the options: [latex] \oint xdy=\int \int _R\left ( \frac{\partial x}{\partial x} -0\right )dxdy=\int \int _Rdxdy[/latex] [latex] \frac{1}{2}\oint xdy-ydx=\frac{1}{2}\int \int _R(1+1)dxdy=\int \int _Rdxdy [/latex] [latex] \oint ydx=\int \int _R(-1)dxdy=-\int \int _Rdxdy [/latex] Hence, 
[latex]\oint ydx [/latex] is not represent the area of the
region.

question:
Question 42 Let [latex] \vec{E}(x,y,z)=2x^2\hat{i}+5y\hat{j}+3z\hat{k}[/latex]. The value of [latex] \int \int \int _V(\vec{\triangledown }\cdot \vec{E})dV[/latex], where [latex] V[/latex] is the
volume enclosed by the unit cube defined by [latex] 0\leq x\leq 1,0\leq y\leq 1 \text{ and }0\leq z\leq 1[/latex], is
solution: Divergence of [latex]\vec{V}, \triangledown \cdot \vec{V}=4x+5+3=4x+8 [/latex] Now, [latex]\int \int \int( \triangledown \cdot \vec{V})dxdydz=\int_{0}^{1}\int_{0}^{1}\int_{0}^{1}(4x+8)dxdydz=\int_{0}^{1}(4x+8)dx=[2x^2+8x]_0^1=10 [/latex]

question:
Question 43 As shown in the figure below, two concentric conducting spherical shells, centered
at [latex]r=0 [/latex] and having radii [latex]r=c [/latex]and [latex]r=d [/latex] are maintained at potentials such that
the potential [latex]V(r) [/latex] at [latex]r=c [/latex] is [latex]V_1[/latex] and [latex]V(r) [/latex] at [latex]r=d [/latex] is [latex]V_2[/latex]. Assume that [latex]V(r) [/latex] depends
only on [latex]r [/latex], where [latex]r [/latex] is the radial distance. The expression for [latex]V(r) [/latex] in the region
between [latex]r=c [/latex]and [latex]r=d [/latex] is
solution:
We have, Laplace equation [latex] \triangledown ^2V=0[/latex]    ...(1) where, 
[latex] \triangledown ^2V=\frac{1}{r^2}\frac{\partial }{\partial r}\left ( r^2\frac{\partial V}{\partial r} \right )+\frac{1}{r^2 \sin \theta }\frac{\partial }{\partial \theta }\left ( \sin \theta  \frac{\partial V}{\partial \theta } \right )+
\frac{1}{r^2 \sin ^2\theta } \frac{\partial^2 V}{\partial \phi ^2}[/latex] V will have only radial component. From equation (1) [latex]\frac{1}{r^2}\frac{\partial }{\partial r}\left ( r^2\frac{\partial V}{\partial r} \right )=0 [/latex] Integrate both side 
[latex] r^2\frac{\partial V}{\partial r} =P[/latex] Again integrate, 
[latex]V=-\frac{P}{r}+Q [/latex] Here, P and  Q are constant. Given: at 
[latex] r=c, V=V_1[/latex] [latex]V_1=-\frac{P}{r}+Q [/latex]    ...(2) at 
[latex] r=d, V=V_2[/latex] [latex]V_2=-\frac{P}{d}+Q [/latex]  ...(3) From eq. (2) & (3) [latex]P=\frac{(V_2-V_1)cd}{d-c} [/latex] [latex] Q=V_1+\frac{d(V_2-V_1)}{d-c}[/latex] From eq. (1), [latex]V=-\frac{(V_2-V_1)cd}{r(d-c)}+V_1+\frac{(V_2-V_1)cd}{(d-c)} [/latex] [latex] V=\frac{(V_1-V_2)cd}{r(d-c)}+\frac{(V_2d-V_1c)}{(d-c)}[/latex]

question: Question 44 Let the probability density function of a random variable [latex]x [/latex] be given as [latex]f(x)=ae^{-2|x|} [/latex] The value of [latex] 'a'[/latex] is _________
solution:
[latex]f(x)=\left\{\begin{matrix}
ae^{2x} &x \lt 0 \\ 
 ae^{-2x} &x \gt 0 
\end{matrix}\right. [/latex] Therefore, [latex] \begin{aligned}
\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }f(x)dx&=1\\
\int_{-\infty }^{0}ae^{2x}dx+\int_{0 }^{\infty }ae^{-2x}dx&=1\\
a\left [ \left [ \frac{e^{2x}}{2} \right ]_{-\infty }^0 +[ \left [ \frac{e^{-2x}}{-2} \right ]^{\infty }_0\right ]&=1\\
a\left [ \frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{2} \right ]&=1\\
a&=1
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 45 In the circuit shown below, the magnitude of the voltage  [latex] V_1[/latex] in volts, across the  [latex] 8k\Omega [/latex] resistor is ______________. (round off to nearest integer)
solution: Apply kVL : [latex]75-(2k)I-0.5V_1=0 [/latex]   ...(1) From circuit: [latex] V_1=(8k)I[/latex] [latex]I=\frac{V_1}{8k} [/latex]   ...(2) From equation (1) & (2) [latex] 75-(2k) \times \frac{V}{8k}-0.5V_1=0[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow V_1=100V[/latex]

question:
Question 46 Two generating units rated for 250 MW and 400 MW have governor speed
regulations of 6% and 6.4%, respectively, from no load to full load. Both the
generating units are operating in parallel to share a load of 500 MW. Assuming free
governor action, the load shared in MW, by the 250 MW generating unit is
_________. (round off to nearest integer)
solution:
Let no-load frequency is 50 Hz. Draw the curve : From the curve, [latex]  \begin{aligned}
\frac{50-f}{3}&=\frac{P_1}{250} \;\;\;..(1)  \\
\frac{50-f}{3.2}&=\frac{P_2}{400} \;\;\;..(2) 
\end{aligned}[/latex] From eq. (1) & (2), [latex] \begin{aligned}
\frac{3P_1}{250}&= \frac{3.2P_2}{400}  \\
3P_1&=2P_2\;\;\;...(3)
\end{aligned} [/latex] Given: 
[latex]P_1+P_2=500[/latex] From eq. (3), [latex] P_1+1.5P_1=500[/latex] [latex] P_1=200MW[/latex]

question:
Question 47 A 20 MVA, 11.2 kV, 4-pole, 50 Hz alternator has an inertia constant of
15 MJ/MVA. If the input and output powers of the alternator are 15 MW and
10 MW, respectively, the angular acceleration in mechanical [latex] degree/s^2[/latex] is
__________. (round off to nearest integer)
solution:
We have, swing equation [latex]\frac{2HS}{\omega _s}\frac{d^2\delta }{dt^2}=P_a [/latex] Put the values, [latex] \begin{aligned}
\frac{2 \times 15 \times 20}{360 \times 50}\frac{d^2\delta }{dt^2}&=15-10\\
\frac{d^2\delta }{dt^2}&=\frac{5 \times 360 \times 50}{2 \times 15 \times 20}\\
&=150 \text{ electric degree per} sec^2\\
\frac{d^2\delta }{dt^2}&=\alpha =\frac{2}{4} \times 150 \text{ Mech. degree/}sec^2\\
&=75\text{ Mech. degree/}sec^2
\end{aligned} [/latex]

question:
Question 48 Consider an ideal full-bridge single-phase DC-AC inverter with a DC bus voltage
magnitude of 1000 V. The inverter output voltage [latex] v(t)[/latex] shown below, is obtained
when diagonal switches of the inverter are switched with 50 % duty cycle. The
inverter feeds a load with a sinusoidal current given by, [latex] i(t)=10 \sin (\omega t-\frac{\pi}{3})A[/latex], 
where [latex] \omega =\frac{2\pi}{T}[/latex]. The active power, in watts, delivered to the load is _________.
(round off to nearest integer)
solution: For [latex]1-\phi  [/latex] invertor, RMS value of fundamental component [latex] V_{01}=\frac{2\sqrt{2}V_s}{\pi}[/latex] Now, Power output [latex] =V_{01}I_{or} \cos \frac{\pi}{3}=\frac{2\sqrt{2}}{\pi} \times 1000 \times \frac{10}{\sqrt{2}} \times \frac{1}{2}=3183.098W[/latex]

question:
Question 49 For the ideal AC-DC rectifier circuit shown in the figure below, the load current
magnitude is [latex]I_{dc} = 15 A [/latex] and is ripple free. The thyristors are fired with a delay angle
of [latex] 45^{\circ}[/latex]. The amplitude of the fundamental component of the source current, in
amperes, is __________. (round off to two decimal places)
solution: Given rectifier circuit is a [latex]1-\phi  [/latex] semiconverter Waveform of source current: [latex] \therefore \; i_{sn}=\sum_{n=1,3,5...}^{\infty }\frac{4I_o}{n\pi} \cos \left ( \frac{n\alpha }{2} \right ) \sin (n\omega t+\phi _n) [/latex] Now, fundamental component, [latex]I_{s1}=\frac{4I_o}{\pi} \cos \left ( \frac{\alpha }{2}  \right )=\frac{4 \times 15}{\pi} \cos \left ( \frac{45^{\circ} }{2}  \right )=17.64A [/latex]

question:
Question 50 A 3-phase grid-connected voltage source converter with DC link voltage of 1000 V
is switched using sinusoidal Pulse Width Modulation (PWM) technique. If the grid
phase current is 10 A and the 3-phase complex power supplied by the converter is
given by [latex](-4000 - j3000) VA[/latex], then the modulation index used in sinusoidal
PWM is ___________. (round off to two decimal places)
solution:
Apparent power, S = (-4000 - j3000) VA or  
[latex] S=5000\angle -143.13^{\circ}VA [/latex] [latex]S=\sqrt{3}V_LI_L [/latex] [latex]  V_L=\frac{5000}{\sqrt{3} \times 10}=288.675V[/latex] We have, Peak,  
[latex]V_{01}=\sqrt{3}M_A\frac{V_s}{2} [/latex] Put the values [latex]\sqrt{2}\times 288.675=\sqrt{3}M_A \times \frac{1000}{2} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \; M_A=0.471[/latex]

question:
Question 51 The steady state current flowing through the inductor of a DC-DC buck boost
converter is given in the figure below. If the peak-to-peak ripple in the output
voltage of the converter is 1 V, then the value of the output capacitor, in [latex]\mu F [/latex], is
_______________. (round off to nearest integer)
solution:
We have for buck boost converter, [latex] \begin{aligned}
 \Delta V_c&= \frac{I_o}{fC}\\ 
where, \; \alpha  &=\frac{T_{ON}}{T}\frac{20}{20+30}=0.4 \\ 
 I_{L(Avg)}&=\frac{16+12}{2}=14A 
\end{aligned}[/latex] For buck-boost converter, [latex]\begin{aligned}
 \frac{I_{o(Avg)}}{I_{L(Avg)}}&=\frac{1}{1-\alpha }\\
\Rightarrow I_L&=I_o(1-\alpha )\\
&=14(1-0.4)=8.4A\\
Given: \; \Delta V_c&=1V\\
Therefore, \; 1&=\frac{0.4 \times 8.4 \times 50 \times 1^{-6}}{C}\\
C&=168\mu F
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 52 A 280 V, separately excited DC motor with armature resistance of [latex]1\Omega  [/latex] and constant
field excitation drives a load. The load torque is proportional to the speed. The
motor draws a current of 30 A when running at a speed of 1000 rpm. Neglect
frictional losses in the motor. The speed, in rpm, at which the motor will run, if an
additional resistance of value [latex]10\Omega  [/latex] is connected in series with the armature, is
_______. (round off to nearest integer)
solution:
Back emf, [latex]E_{b1}=280-30 \times 1 =250V [/latex] When additional [latex] 10\Omega[/latex] resistance connected in
series with armature. [latex]E_{b2}=280-(10+1) I_{a_2} =280-11I_{a_2} [/latex] Given:
[latex] \tau \propto N[/latex] We know, 
[latex] \tau \propto \phi I_a \text{ (Here, }\phi \rightarrow constant)[/latex] So, [latex]\begin{aligned}
\tau &\propto I_a \\
\therefore \; N &\propto I_a \\
or \; \frac{N_2}{N_1}&=\frac{I_{a_2}}{I_{a_1}}\\
I_{a_2}&=N_2 \times \frac{30}{1000}\\
\therefore \; E_{b_2}&=280-\left ( 11 \times \frac{30}{1000} \right )N_2\\
&\text{We also have,}\\
E_b &\propto\phi \omega \\
\therefore \frac{E_{b_2}}{E_{b_1}}&=\frac{N_2}{N_1}\\
&\frac{280-\left ( 11 \times \frac{30}{1000} \right )N_2}{250}=\frac{N_2}{1000}\\
\Rightarrow N_2&=482.758rpm
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 53 A 4-pole induction motor with inertia of 0.1 [latex]kg-m^2[/latex] drives a constant load torque of
2 Nm. The speed of the motor is increased linearly from 1000 rpm to 1500 rpm in
4 seconds as shown in the figure below. Neglect losses in the motor. The energy, in
joules, consumed by the motor during the speed change is ____________. (round
off to nearest integer)
solution:
We have [latex]\begin{aligned}
J\frac{d\omega }{dt}&=\tau _e-\tau _L\\
J\omega \frac{d\omega }{dt}&=P_e-P_L \;\;(\because P=\tau \omega )\\
\therefore P_e&=J\omega \frac{d\omega }{dt}+P_L\\
E&=\int P_edt\\
R&=J\int_{1000}^{1500}\omega d\omega +\int_{1000}^{1500}P_Ldt\\
&=\frac{J}{2}\left ( \frac{2 \pi}{60} \right )^2[1500^2-1000^2]+\frac{2 \pi \tau }{60}\int_{1000}^{1500}Ndt\\
&=\frac{0.1}{2}\left ( \frac{2 \pi}{60} \right )^2\times 125 \times 10^4+\frac{2 \pi}{60} \times 2\times [1000 \times 4+\frac{1}{2} \times 500 \times 4]\\
&=1732.586J
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 54 A star-connected 3-phase, 400 V, 50 kVA, 50 Hz synchronous motor has a
synchronous reactance of 1 ohm per phase with negligible armature resistance. The
shaft load on the motor is 10 kW while the power factor is 0.8 leading. The loss in
the motor is 2 kW. The magnitude of the per phase excitation emf of the motor, in
volts, is __________. (round off to nearest integer).
solution:
Power input[latex] = 10 + 2 = 12 kW[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned}
P&=\sqrt{3}VI \cos\phi \\
I_a&=\frac{10 \times 10^3}{\sqrt{3} \times 400 \times 0.8}\\
&=21.65\angle 36.86^{\circ}A
\end{aligned}[/latex] We have, Emf equation for motor [latex]\begin{aligned}
\bar{E_{ph}}&=\bar{V_{ph}}-\bar{I_{a}}\bar{Z_{s}}\\
&=\frac{400}{\sqrt{3}}-21.65\angle 36.83^{\circ}\times 1\angle 90^{\circ}\\
&=244.542\angle -4.062^{\circ}V
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 55 A 3-phase, 415 V, 4-pole, 50 Hz induction motor draws 5 times the rated current at
rated voltage at starting. It is required to bring down the starting current from the
supply to 2 times of the rated current using a 3-phase autotransformer. If the
magnetizing impedance of the induction motor and no load current of the
autotransformer is neglected, then the transformation ratio of the autotransformer is
given by _______. (round off to two decimal places).
solution:
We have [latex] I_L=x^2I_{sc}[/latex] Here, 
[latex] I_L=2I_f[/latex] and 
[latex]I_{sc}=5I_f [/latex] From the above eqiations. [latex]2I_f=x^25I_f\Rightarrow x=\sqrt{\frac{2}{5}}=0.6324 [/latex]

question: Question 56 As you grow older, an injury to your ________

Question 57 In a 500 m race, P and Q have speeds in the ratio of 3?4. Q starts the race
when P has already covered 140 m. What is the distance between P and Q (in m) when P wins the race?
solution:
Given: [latex]\frac{S_P}{S_Q}=\frac{3}{4} [/latex] So, 
[latex]S_P=3x [/latex] and 
[latex] S_Q=4x[/latex] Let at time t, P reach end point [latex] 3x \times t=360[/latex] [latex]xt=120 [/latex] Now, at time t, distance covered by 
[latex]Q=4xt=4 \times 120=480m [/latex] Hence, Difference
[latex] =500-480=20m[/latex]

question: Question 58 Three bells P, Q, and R are rung periodically in a school. P is rung every 20 minutes; Q is rung every 30 minutes and R is rung every 50 minutes. If all the three bells are rung at 12:00 PM, when will the three bells ring together again the next time?
solution:
LCM of (20, 30, 50) = 300 min. Hence, the bells are together ring again = 12 :
00 + 5 = 5 : 00 PM

question:
Question 59 Given below are two statements and four conclusions drawn based on the
statements. Statement 1: Some bottles are cups. Statement 2: All cups are knives. Conclusion I: Some bottles are knives. Conclusion II: Some knives are cups. Conclusion III: All cups are bottles. Conclusion IV: All knives are cups. Which one of the following options can be logically inferred?
solution: Draw Venn Diagram Hence, Only conclusion I & II correct.

options.A: Only conclusion I and conclusion II are correct
options.B: Only conclusion II and conclusion III are correct
options.C: Only conclusion II and conclusion IV are correct
options.D: Only conclusion III and conclusion IV are correct

question:
Question 60 The figure below shows the front and rear view of a disc, which is shaded with
identical patterns. The disc is flipped once with respect to any one of the fixed
axes 1-1, 2-2 or 3-3 chosen uniformly at random. What is the probability that the disc DOES NOT retain the same front and rear
views after the flipping operation?
solution: Case (i): Rotate with 1-1 axis Front view [latex] \rightleftharpoons [/latex] rear view Case (ii) rotate with 2-2 & 3-3 axis Front view [latex] \neq [/latex] rear view Therefore, probability = 2/3

question:
Question 61 Altruism is the human concern for the wellbeing of others. Altruism has been
shown to be motivated more by social bonding, familiarity and identification of
belongingness to a group. The notion that altruism may be attributed to empathy
or guilt has now been rejected. Which one of the following is the CORRECT logical inference based on the
information in the above passage?

options.A: Humans engage in altruism due to guilt but not empathy
options.B: Humans engage in altruism due to empathy but not guilt
options.C: Humans engage in altruism due to group identification but not empathy
options.D: Humans engage in altruism due to empathy but not familiarity

question:
Question 62 There are two identical dice with a single letter on each of the faces. The
following six letters: Q, R, S, T, U, and V, one on each of the faces. Any of the
six outcomes are equally likely. The two dice are thrown once independently at random. What is the probability that the outcomes on the dice were composed only of
any combination of the following possible outcomes: Q, U and V?

Question 63 The price of an item is 10% cheaper in an online store S compared to the price
at another online store M. Store S charges Rs.150 for delivery. There are no
delivery charges for orders from the store M. A person bought the item from the
store S and saved Rs. 100.
What is the price of the item at the online store S (in Rs.) if there are no other
charges than what is described above?
solution:
Let cost of M is 100x and S is 90x. Delicery charge of M is 0 and S is 150. Therefore,
100x - (90x + 150) = 100 So, x = 25 Hence, price of item store in S = 90 x 25 = Rs. 2250

question:
Question 64 The letters P, Q, R, S, T and U are to be placed one per vertex on a regular convex
hexagon, but not necessarily in the same order. Consider the following statements: (1) The line segment joining R and S is longer than the line segment joining
P and Q.
(2) The line segment joining R and S is perpendicular to the line segment
joining P and Q.
(3) The line segment joining R and U is parallel to the line segment joining T
and Q. Based on the above statements, which one of the following options is
CORRECT?
solution: Hence, option (A) will be correct

options.A: The line segment joining R and T is parallel to the line segment joining Q and S
options.B: The line segment joining T and Q is parallel to the line joining P and U
options.C:
The line segment joining R and P is perpendicular to the line segment joining U
and Q
options.D:
The line segment joining Q and S is perpendicular to the line segment joining R
and P

question:
Question 65 An ant is at the bottom-left corner of a grid (point P) as shown above. It aims to
move to the top-right corner of the grid. The ant moves only along the lines
marked in the grid such that the current distance to the top-right corner strictly
decreases. Which one of the following is a part of a possible trajectory of the ant during
the movement?
